columns.text: In this problem, we will learn about financial ratios.

Before we begin, let us first define financial ratio.

**Financial ratio** is a quantitative method of obtaining an idea of a company's profitability, solvency, efficiency, liquidity, coverage, and market value.

## a. Quick ratio

This financial ratio shows if the company can meet its short-term obligations with its most liquid assets.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Quick ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Inventory}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## b. Cash ratio

This financial ratio shows if the company can meet its short-term obligations using only its cash and cash equivalents.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Cash + Marketable Securities}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## c. Total Asset Turnover

This financial ratio shows if the company is efficient in relation to its total assets in generating revenue or sales.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Total Asset Turnover}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Net Sales}} {\text{Average Total Assets}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## d. Equity multiplier

This financial ratio measures a portion of a company's assets that is financed by shareholders' equity.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Equity multiplier}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Assets}} {\text{Total Shareholders' Equity}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## e. Long-term debt ratio

This financial ratio show the company's ability to pay for a long-term debt.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Long-term debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Long-term debt }} {\text{Shareholders' equity}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## f. Times interest earned

This financial ratio shows how easily a company can pay its debts with its current income.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Times interest earned}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Earnings before Interest \& Taxes }} {\text{Interest expense}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## g. Profit margin

This financial ratio shows the percentage of profit a company produces from its operations.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Operating profit margin
}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Operating profit}} {\text{Net sales}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## h. Return on assets

This financial ratio shows if the company is efficient or profitable in relation to the assets or resources it owns or controls.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Return on assets}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Net Income}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## i. Return on equity

This financial ratio shows if the company's value is growing at an acceptable rate.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Return on equity}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Net Income}} {\text{Shareholders' Equity}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

## j. Price–earnings ratio

This financial ratio measures the company's current share price relative to its earnings per share.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Price–earnings ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Share Price}} {\text{Earnings per share}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$
